newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle bids at $63 passed - trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle bids at $63 passed - trade.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets early Tuesday remained at a standstill, with packer bids at $63.00 per cwt passed by owners pricing cattle at $65.00 to $66.00, feedlot sources said.
Lower CME live cattle futures diminished bullish outlooks for fed cattle prices this week, they said.

Feedlot managers on Monday expected fed cattle to trade steady to firm, compared with last week's sales of $64.00. However, lower futures and the lack of active beef sales now had the managers anticipating mostly steady values.
Beef prices Monday were quoted up $0.03 to $0.41 per cwt, with 127 fabricated loads sold, USDA said.
Active beef sales Friday at higher prices had spurred expectations for continued brisk business Monday, which would lend support to fed cattle prices, feedlot sources said.

Heavy, wet snowfall in central and northeastern Nebraska overnight Monday and early Tuesday fueled concern that cattle would be stressed, particularly if strong winds develop behind the storm and chill cattle further, the sources said.
